Summer school in digital humanities

Py4SHS

A week of intensive Python training for all your humanities project.

4th-8th september, Campus du Saulcy, Metz, France.

Register

Who is this for ?

Are you a SHS researcher wanting to learn more about digital science can help your projects but have never known where to start ? Then Py4SHS is for you !

Discover the captivating world of digital humanities with our exciting Summer School program! Join us for an immersive and enriching experience that combines tradition with technology. Unlock the power of digital tools as we explore the intersection of humanities and the digital age. Immerse yourself in interactive workshops led by renowned experts in coding, data visualization, and interactive storytelling. Expand your horizons and gain practical skills that will revolutionize the way you approach art, history, literature, and culture. Connect with a vibrant community of like-minded individuals who share your passion for knowledge and curiosity. Challenge conventional boundaries and become a trailblazer in the field of digital humanities. Embrace the opportunities that lie ahead and be prepared to shape the future of scholarship. Don't miss out on this incredible opportunity to enhance your academic journey. Join us at the py4SHS 2023 Summer School and embark on a transformative learning experience.

Schedule

One week of intensive training: 3 hours of theoretical course in the morning, 3 hours of practical work in the afternoon.

Day 1

9-9:30am: Welcome breakfast.


9:30-11:30: Keynote speaker: An Introduction to Digital Humanities, by Pr. Rey.


11:30-14:30: Lunch break.


14:30-17:30: Hands-on course: Setting up your environment, by Céline Lemarinier.

Day 3

9-9:30am: Welcome breakfast.


9:30-11:30: Featured speaker: An introduction to Computer Vision, G. Charbonnier


11:30-14:30: Lunch break.


14:30-17:30: Hands-on course: Using Kraken for manuscript recognition, G. Charbonnier.

Day 2

9-9:30am: Welcome breakfast.


9:30-11:30: Featured speaker: An Introduction to SQL and NoSQL databases, by C. Lemarinier.


11:30-14:30: Lunch break.


14:30-17:30: Hands-on course: Manipulating data using SQL, by C. Lemarinier.

Day 5

9-9:30am: Welcome breakfast.


9:30-11:30: Featured speaker: An Introduction to Bibliometrics, by S. Garcia.


11:30-14:30: Lunch break.


14:30-17:30: Hands-on course: Manipulating bibliometrics by S. Garcia.

Day 4

9-9:30am: Welcome breakfast.


9:30-11:30: Featured speaker: An introduction to Natural Language Processing, by S. Hayek.


11:30-14:30: Lunch break.


14:30-17:30: Hands-on course: Applying Natural Language Processing methods for text classification, by S. Hayek.

Organization Comitee

Pr. Frédérique Rey, biblical scholar and specialist in the possible applications of I/A to humanities.

S. Hayek, phD.

Featured speakers

G. Charbonnier

G. Charbonnier is a computer scientist from Grenoble: he is the lead tech at the QUARA startup, specialized in sensors collections and analysis.

C. Lemarinier

C. Lemarinier is a senior software developer at Atos-Bull, where she develops next generation supercomputers. She has a strong experience in API development, SQL and NoSQL database.

S. Garcia

S. Hayek

S. Hayek holds a PhD in computer science and has had several experience working on digital humanities project: analysis of similarities between the Septuagint and the New Testament, stemmatology of the Hebrew Bible...

F. Rey

F. Rey is a biblical scholar, leading several project in digital humanities.

Venue

The summer school will take place from the 4th to the 8th September, as the Saulcy Campus, in the center of Metz. If you need help finding affordable housing, please contact us.

Register to join us for this exciting week !
